awd_titl_txt: Molecular, Biochemical, and Structural Studies of the Mechanism of S-RNase-Based Self-Incompatibility in Petunia
awd_abstract_narration:
Most flowering plants produce flowers with the male reproductive organ, the anther, and female reproductive organ, the pistil, located in close proximity.  This arrangement would allow the pollen produced by the anther to land on the top of the pistil to result in self-pollination and consequent inbreeding.  Inbreeding is deleterious to any organism, as it causes reduced fitness in progeny.  Flowering plants have adopted self-incompatibility (SI), which allows the pistil to reject self-pollen to prevent inbreeding, but accept non-self pollen to promote outcrossing.  Since Charles Darwin first documented this phenomenon in a monograph published in 1876, SI has attracted the interest of a wide spectrum of biologists.  The PI has identified a pistil protein and 17 pollen proteins that are key players in mediating SI in Petunia inflata, a wild relative of garden petunia.  In this project, the PI and his collaborator will use a combination of molecular, biochemical, genetic, genomic, and structural approaches to determine how the 17 pollen proteins and a single pistil protein work together to allow the pistil to specifically reject self-pollen.  The results have wider implications for the study of many other biological systems employing self/non-self recognition.  The genes for these proteins could be used to facilitate hybrid-seed production, which, if accomplished, would provide tremendous agronomic benefits.  The PI will engage graduate and undergraduate students in this project to prepare them for future research careers, and will offer summer research opportunity for high school students through Penn State's Upward Bound Math and Science Program. 

In S-RNase-based self-incompatibility in Petunia inflata, the polymorphic S-locus controls the outcome of pollination; matching of the pollen S-haplotype with either S-haplotype of the pistil results in growth inhibition of pollen tubes.  The PI has shown that the S-RNase gene controls pistil specificity and identified 17 S-locus F-box (SLF) genes in S2-haplotype that collectively control pollen specificity.  In this project, the PI will complete the determination of 187 interaction relationships between all 17 SLF proteins and 11 allelic variants of S-RNase.  These results will be used to study the biochemical basis of differential interactions between SLF proteins and S-RNases, and select SLF/S-RNase pairs for X-ray structural study of the interactions.  Bacterial Artificial Chromosome (BAC) clones collectively containing the S-RNase and 17 SLF genes have been isolated, sequenced, and assembled, totaling ~3.1 Mbp.  To fill gaps in the S-locus sequence, additional BAC clones will be isolated and sequenced.  The PI has shown that all 17 SLF proteins form similar SCF complexes, but the Cullin1 and Skp1 components (PiCUL1-P and PiSSK1) are pollen-specific.  The effect of knockout and suppressed expression of PiCUL1-P and PiSSK1 will be examined, and the X-ray structure of the SCFSLF complex will be determined.  The PI has found that SLF proteins themselves are subject to ubiquitin-mediated degradation by the 26S proteasome, and identified proteins that may be involved in regulating the dynamics of the SCFSLF complex.  The role of these proteins will be examined.  All X-ray crystallization experiments will be performed in the lab of the collaborator.

por.por_cntn:
Plants have evolved interspecific and intraspecific reproductive barriers to maintain species identity and permit genetic variability within species. Intraspecific reproductive barriers are particularly important for plants producing perfect flowers, containing both male and female reproductive organs, because this floral anatomy is conducive to inbreeding. Self-incompatibility is an intraspecific reproductive barrier that allows pistils to reject self-pollen to prevent inbreeding and accept non-self pollen for outcrossing. Self-incompatibility in the Solanaceae family is controlled by pistil-specific and pollen-specific genes at the polymorphic S-locus. Variants of the S-locus, S-haplotypes, are designated as S1, S2, S3, etc. If the S-haplotype carried by the pollen matches one of the S-haplotypes carried by the pistil, the pistil recognizes pollen as self-pollen and rejects tube growth in the pistil. If the pollen S-haplotype is not carried by the pistil, the pistil recognizes pollen as non-self pollen and allows it to effect fertilization.   

 

The PI?s lab uses Petunia inflata as a model to study how pistils specifically inhibit growth of self-pollen tubes. Prior to the start of this project, the lab had (1) identified the S-RNase gene as the gene encoding the pistil determinant and 17 S-locus F-box (SLF) genes that might collectively encode the pollen determinant; (2) used co-immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry to identify pollen-specific PiSSK1 and PiCUL1-P as the Skp1 and Cullin1 components, respectively, of the SCFSLF complex, and to show that all 17 SLF proteins of S2-haplotype and S3-haplotype are assembled into similar SCF complexes; (3) proposed the collaborative non-self recognition model with the Seiji Takayama lab to explain how a single polymorphic S-RNase and multiple polymorphic SLF proteins function in SI. 

 

The first goal of this project was to examine the validity of the collaborative non-self recognition model. The lab used an in vivo functional assay to determine interaction relationships between 17 SLF proteins and 11 S-RNases, and used CRISPR/Cas9 to knock out S2-SLF1 (SLF1 of S2-haplotype) and examined the effect on the SI behavior of S2 pollen. All the results supported the predictions of the model that, for a given S-haplotype, each SLF only interacts with a subset of its non-self S-RNases, and none of the SLF proteins interact with their self S-RNase. The lab used CRISPR/Cas9 to separately knock out PiSSK1 and PiCUL1-P, and the results supported the predictions of the model that an SLF is a component of an SCF complex involved in mediating ubiquitination and degradation of non-self S-RNase(s). The lab found that another pollen-specific Cullin1, PiCUL1-B, functions redundantly with PiCUL1-P, and performed evolutionary analyses of Cullin1 homologs in eudicots.

 

The second goal was to characterize the sequence of the S-locus region of S2-haplotype containing the S-RNase gene and 17 SLF genes. The lab analyzed ~3.1 Mb sequence, and the major findings include identification of 28 additional genes and putative SLF parent genes which may contribute to the generation of SLF genes via retrotransposition. 

 

The third objective was to examine the dynamic life cycle of the SCFSLF complex. The lab used CRISPR/Cas9 to separately knock out pollen-specific PiDCN1 and PiUBC12 to examine their potential role in activation of SCFSLF to allow SLF proteins to function in SI. The results suggested that other DCN1-like protein(s) and UBC12 protein(s) function redundantly with PiDCN1 and PiUBC12 in SI.

 

This project has trained two graduate students (one female and one male) and seven undergraduate students (two female and five male). Both graduate students received their Ph.D. degrees. Three of the undergraduate students conducted research under REU support, and one completed an honors thesis. The lab hosted summer research of 19 high school students (16 female and 3 male; 9 Hispanic, 9 African American, and 1 Asian American) from 2017 to 2019 as part of Penn State Upward Bound Summer Academy for Creative Studies, which brings to campus high school students from underrepresented groups in inner cities, who will be first-generation college students in their families. The lab hosted summer research of two State College High School students (one female and one male) in 2021.

 

The results obtained in this project are relevant to a variety of fundamental biological processes in eukaryotes. The use of multiple SLF proteins, each interacting with a subset of its non-self S-RNases, provides a model system for studying the biochemical and structural bases for interactions between F-box proteins and their substrates. The findings that three of the four subunits of SCFSLF specifically function in self-incompatibility, and that no other pollen-expressed Skp1s or Cullin1s can substitute for PiSSK1, or PiCUL1-P and PiCUL1-B, provide an opportunity to study the biochemical and structural bases for the assembly of this class of E3 ubiquitin ligase. Study of proteins required for activation of SCFSLFshed light on the significance of this regulation. All the genes studied in this project could facilitate the goal of introducing self-incompatibility into self-compatible crop species for hybrid seed production.

 


Last Modified: 03/07/2023
Modified by: Teh-Hui Kao
